Situation1: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I stand at the edge of the pool, whistle in hand, eyes fixed on a group of teenagers laughing and pushing each other dangerously close to the no-diving signs. As a lifeguard, I know I have to enforce the rules, keep everyone safe, and not let anything slide. My supervisor expects vigilance, and parents trust me with their children’s lives. But as I watch the water ripple, my mind drifts to something else—my savings, carefully set aside for years, meant for my pilgrimage to Mecca. This year, my friends are going, and they keep sending me messages, urging me to join them. The money I’ve saved is just enough, but if I take time off now, I risk losing this job, and the pool needs me during the busy summer. The pressure builds inside me, the weight of duty and faith pulling me in opposite directions. I grip the whistle tighter, feeling the tension between the responsibility to protect these kids and the longing to fulfill a pillar of my faith. The laughter of the teenagers echoes, and my heart pounds as I stand caught between two worlds, unsure which call to answer.
